Comment: **From Ryan Teague Beckwith, newsletter editor:**  In each case, Trump is trying to get something he wants: a smaller federal workforce, Greenland, a higher birthrate, fewer immigrants. But to get that, someone else has to give up something of value: their job, their sovereignty, their sleep, their home. And the alternatives for Trump to achieve those goals are less attractive, ranging from mass firings to mass deportations to war.  I’ve long thought that more government programs should involve direct cash payments, which cut overhead costs while giving recipients the freedom to decide how best to use the money. And such ideas aren’t exactly new: Democratic Sen. Cory Booker has long called for giving each newborn “baby bonds” that could be cashed in later in life, while then-candidate Kamala Harris pitched a $6,000 tax credit for parents of newborns during her 2024 run.  But those payments were framed as a way to help people who were already doing something, not to provide an incentive for them to do a thing in the first place. Comment: Unfortunately, because the press and influencers have normalized Trump, many voters think the Republican Party is still a legitimate political entity. Everything done to hold Republicans accountable, particularly Trump, gets broadcast to the public through a lens of political persecution. I think this is why Biden and Dems were so timid to make bold moves in 2021-2024: if they move first, they play into the conservative persecution narrative. They were hoping voters would hold Republicans accountable at the ballot box. Whoops.  I’m interested in seeing how the German declaration of AfD as an illegal extremist group plays out. If enough voters are sympathetic with AfD, it’ll fizzle. But I think Germany leaders were smart to wait for this moment: the idiocy and cruelty of Trump’s first 100 days have galvanized pro-democracy factions around the world, and depressed turnout for far-right groups.
